trial_identification.studytitle: Community-based pulmonary rehabilitation in people with Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) - economic benefit?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Community-based pulmonary rehabilitation in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), the clinical and economic effects

interventions.interventions: 6 weeks of twice weekly supervised training compared to usual care. The sessions will be supervised by an experienced physiotherapist in pulmonary rehaiblitation. The duration of sessions is 60 minutes. EAch sessions will consist of a combination of walking training, cycling and light upper and lower limb weights. The training is all conducted in a group setting.
interventions.comparator: Usual care (no exercise training or education), usual follow up with the GP and respiratory physician as required by the patient

primaryOutcome.outcome: QALYs Healthcare usage from Medicare Benefits Scheme and Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme Hospitalisation rates

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Incremental shuttle walk distance (ISWD) - exercise capacity
Hospital anxiety and depression scale - psychological symptoms
St George's respiratory questionnaire - health related quality of life

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis of COPD (Physician and FEV1/FVC < 70% predicted) with stage 2 to 4 and significant smoking history of a minimum of 10 pack years Exertional dyspnoea of 2-4 according to MMRC
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Comorbidities limiting safety to exercise Inability to understand English Completion of pulmonary rehabilitation within previous 18 months Acute exacerbation of COPD within last 4 weeks

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Comparison of groups using repeated measures ANOVA or Mann Whitney U tests with intention-to-treat analysis.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Western Hospital Gordon Street Footscray 3011 Victoria

fundingsource.fundingname: Victorian Tuberculosis and Lung Foundation - Edgar Tatnell Grant
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Victorian Tuberculosis and Lung Foundation 44 Brookes Street, Bowen Hills Queensland 4006

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to determine if a community-based exercise program for people with COPD is economically beneficial and associated with improvements in exercise capacity and quality of life
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Kathy McCann - October 2011 Findings presented at Australian Physiotherapy Association

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Western Health Human Research Ethics committee
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Western Health Gordon Street, Footscray, 3011 Victoria
